column1: El Reno is a city in and county seat of Canadian County
column3: United States. As of the 2010 census
column4: the city population was 16
column5: 729. The city was begun shortly after the 1889 land rush and named for the nearby Fort Reno. It is located in Central Oklahoma
column6: about 25 miles (40 km) west of downtown Oklahoma City.

column1: The city was originally located about 5 miles (8.0 km) north of its present location
column2: on the banks of the North Canadian River
column3: bearing the name Reno City
column4: which caused its mail to get mixed up with mail for Reno

column6: it was moved to its present location and changed its name to El Reno. This word is Spanish for "the reindeer". The town
column8: got its name from the nearby Fort Reno; reindeer are not native to Oklahoma.

column2: the land of Canadian County belonged to Cheyenne and Arapaho tribes
column3: but in 1874
column4: Fort Reno was established and General Philip Sheridan took commanded. Sheridan named the fort in honor of his friend
column6: who was killed in the American Civil War. The grounds of the old fort became home to a research laboratory for the U.S. Department of Agriculture in 1948. The laboratory studies environmentally sustainable forage and livestock production
column7: contributing to preservation of the Great Plains of North America.

column1: El Reno is located on the 98th meridian west
column2: which allowed the eastern side to be opened to non-Indian settlement in the Land Rush of 1889. The western side was opened in the 1892 opening of the Cheyenne and Arapaho lands. It was subsequently selected as the land district office for the 1901 land lottery drawings.During World War II
column3: Fort Reno
column4: about 5 mi (8.0 km) northwest of El Reno
column5: was the site of a prisoner of war camp
column6: and today contains a POW cemetery
column7: with stones bearing the names of German and Italian prisoners who died there.

column2: restricted to male prisoners under the age of 35
column3: was constructed about 2 miles (3.2 km) west of El Reno in 1935. Renamed the Federal Correctional Institution of El Reno in the mid-1970s
column4: the population expanded to include men of all ages. It became the fifth-largest prison in the U.S. It is still one of the largest employers in El Reno.El Reno is one of few cities in Oklahoma to have a streetcar in operation in the downtown area: the Heritage Express Trolley At one time
column5: the city possessed a terminal and repair facility for the Chicago
column6: Rock Island and Pacific Railroad (CRI&P or "Rock Island")
column7: which employed a large number of people.  The CRI&P went bankrupt in 1979. The railyards have remained vacant property. The old train depot and some other buildings were acquired by the Canadian County Historical Society for use as part of a museum complex. The 1954 film noir Human Desire includes locomotive and yard scenes filmed in the El Reno rail yards.

column1: El Reno is a Main Street community. The Oklahoma Main Street Program is a downtown revitalization program and the El Reno Program won the Great American Main Street Award in 2006.
The town is noted for its annual Fried Onion Burger Day Festival
column2: which is always the first Saturday in May. Burger Day is when visitors can witness the cooking of the world's largest fried onion hamburger
column3: weighing over 850 lb (390 kg). The giant burger contains all the important parts of the famous El Reno fried onion burgers
column4: which include meat
column7: and mustard all between two giant buns. Not only do festival goers get to watch the massive burger be built and cooked
column8: but they are also allowed to help eat the monstrosity. Volunteers divide the giant burger into individual-sized portions with burger-sized cookie cutters. Other volunteers shuttle back and forth from the burger to the crowd
column9: delivering the free portions to anyone wanting a piece. The idea of the fried onion burger was born out of necessity during the Great Depression
column10: when onions were used to stretch out the meat supply.

column3: Sid's Diner was featured on the Food Network series Top 5 Restaurants
column4: with the fried-onion burger being highlighted. Sid's Diner has also been featured on the Travel Channel series Man v. Food.

column3: El Reno was hit by a multiple-vortex tornado. The tornado set a record with a width of 2.6 miles (4.2 km). The Weather Channel's Mike Bettes was hit by this storm
column4: but survived it. Tim Samaras
column6: and TWISTEX colleague Carl Young lost their lives near the Regional Airport. Paul and Young were ejected from their Chevrolet Cobalt by the tornado's subvortex
column7: while Tim was still buckled in the passenger's seat next to Young's driving seat. Local amateur chaser Richard Henderson lost his life in that same area. Before the tornado struck him
column8: Henderson snapped a picture of it from his mobile phone and sent that picture to a friend. Dan Robinson of St. Louis
column9: Missouri successfully escaped the tornado with a few injuries. He was a few hundred meters ahead of the TWISTEX crew.

column1: An EF3 tornado struck southern parts of El Reno on May 25
column3: the tornado damaged a service station before moving east-northeastward
column4: crossing Interstate 40
column5: and damaging billboards before striking a motel and a mobile home park at U.S. Highway 81
column6: both of which suffered significant damage. One part of the motel had most of its second-floor walls destroyed
column7: and several mobile homes were destroyed
column8: killing two people and injuring many others. East of Highway 81
column9: the tornado damaged an automobile service building and a house on Route 66. The tornado then caused tree damage before dissipating on Alfadale Road north of Route 66. The tornado had a maximum estimated width of 75 yards (69 m) and injured 19 people.

column8: and it was the strongest earthquake in Oklahoma history prior to the November 5

column1: El Reno has endured numerous weather-related incidents in recent years:

column3: El Reno was hit by a severe ice storm that left most of the city without power for several days and caused thousands of dollars of damage in downed trees and powerlines. The storm brought around two inches of ice
column4: with as much as 6 inches over the following days. All of Canadian County was designated as a Federal Disaster Area.

column3: El Reno suffered damage from one of the many tornadoes that formed from the same storm that produced the infamous F5 tornado that day. Parts of Redlands Community College were damaged.

column1: El Reno has weathered several ice storms in recent years
column4: storm that left up to two inches of ice in the hardest-hit locations.

column3: as the entire state endured one of the driest summers on record.
drought conditions allowed an area wildfire to grow to burn over 1000 acres (4 km2).  Winds carried the smoke into the Oklahoma City metro area
column4: spurring thousands of calls to emergency services by concerned residents.

column3: a rare anticyclonic tornado hit El Reno's municipal airport
column4: causing damage to the hangars and small airplanes.

column3: a tornado ripped through the south and east sides of the city. At least one injury occurred when the tornado knocked over a truck and semitrailer on I-40.
Tropical Storm Erin dumped over 10 inches (250 mm) of rain on El Reno and the surrounding area.  This caused extensive flooding.
a violent long-track tornado passed through the El Reno area
column4: causing extensive damage and killing nine people. The tornado was given an EF5 rating after reviewing the damage.

column3: the 2013 El Reno tornado
column4: the widest tornado ever documented
column5: hit El Reno. The tornado was an estimated 2.6 miles in width and had a recorded wind speed of >301 mph
column6: one of the two highest wind speeds on record along with winds observed in the 1999 Bridge Creek–Moore tornado. It hit the outskirts of the city
column7: prompting a tornado emergency for El Reno and surrounding cities. The tornado killed eight people

column3: a tornado that has been rated at EF3 struck around 10:28 pm. It struck a mobile home park and a motel
column4: killing two people.
